image.altText: An AI-generated image of two people in a cafe.

props.synopsis: Artificial intelligence is being used to generate child abuse material, and police are increasingly worried about its spread. But AI may also be able to help investigators.

title.children: This image is AI-generated. It's innocent, but there are others police are very worried about

image.altText: Composite image of NSW Premier Chris Minns and a police officer at a media conference.

props.synopsis: NSW Police call on the public to help them identify members of the crowd who disguised themselves during Monday's riot outside a Sydney church after a bishop was stabbed.

title.children: Police 'cannot respond to calls' after rioters damaged cars in wake of Sydney bishop's stabbing

image.altText: The PM speaking next to the AFP commissioner Reece Kershaw and ASIO boss Mike Burgess

props.synopsis: Anthony Albanese is fast discovering why his prime ministerial predecessor Scott Morrison took the unorthodox approach of being secretly sworn into a raft of ministries, having been reminded that a PM's power only extends so far when it comes to immigration visas.

title.children: In vouching for Bollard Man, Albanese set himself an uncomfortable precedent

image.altText: Patrick Halley wears medals and holds his Gunner's Wings medal

props.synopsis: A Vietnam War veteran who was involved in carrying out hazardous operations against well-armed Viet Cong guerilla forces and soldiers has finally received his award for service, more than 50 years after returning home.

title.children: Private Halley was reading a book on war memorabilia when he realised he was 50 years overdue for a service award

image.altText: Woolworths shopfront at Montague Markets in West End, Brisbane.

props.synopsis: Today Woolworths admitted in court that it short-changed at least 1,235 former Victorian employees by not properly paying their long service leave entitlements.

title.children: Woolworths admits to underpaying staff  $1.24m

image.altText: A man with a beard looking at the camera, serious, not smiling.

props.synopsis: NSW man Adrian Talbot disputes reports 500 horse carcasses were found on his property, saying the number was closer to 30 or 40, and the animals were humanely euthanased.

title.children: Property operator says butchered horses discovered by council were killed to feed his dogs

image.altText: A red tailed black cockatoo and musk lorikeet at a wildlife sanctuary

props.synopsis: A red-tailed black cockatoo and a musk lorikeet have become inseparable, with the smaller bird often found under the wing of the cockatoo at Tasmania's Bonorong Wildlife Sanctuary.

title.children: Unlikely friendship between cockatoo and lorikeet 'bamboozles' wildlife sanctuary visitors

image.altText: A window on a tall building with black streaks of smoke damage smeared across it.

props.synopsis: Fire authorities have warned of the growing risk of lithium batteries after 50 residents were evacuated from a building due to an exploding mobile phone power bank.

title.children: Fire authorities warn of lithium-ion battery risks after two students narrowly escape Melbourne fire

image.altText: An adult lies in a hospital bed.

props.synopsis: Western Australia records its first meningococcal death since 2020, with two other adults in hospital with the disease, although the cases are not linked.

title.children: West Australian dies from meningococcal, state’s first death from disease since 2020 with two more in hospital

image.altText: A concept image of Toondah Harbour

props.synopsis: Earlier this month Tanya Plibersek released an interim decision that found removing 58.7 hectares from the internationally protected wetland was an "unacceptable impact".

title.children: 'It will not go ahead': Company withdraws bid to develop protected wetlands after environment minister's interim refusal

image.altText: A man in a suit holds his hand over his eyes from the sun as he speaks into a microphone

props.synopsis: Experts say the allegations against him and support for his party are just part of a "concerning" shift towards the far-right and extremism across Europe.

title.children: A German far-right leader allegedly used a Nazi slogan twice — his 'extremist' party is one of the country's highest-polling

image.altText: smoking generic

props.synopsis: British politicians are working to pass a law similar to one introduced to Tasmanian parliament in 2015 that would have banned the sale of tobacco to people born after January 1, 2000.

title.children: The UK is a step closer to banning cigarettes for younger generations. Could it happen in Australia as well?

image.altText: Raina Cruise wearing sunglasses outdoors.

props.synopsis: Anti-vaccine protester Raina Cruise is found guilty of intentionally causing harm to a police officer after trial by judge alone.

title.children: Failed SA Senate candidate who tore hair from police officer found guilty of assault

image.altText: James Warburton

props.synopsis: Seven West Media chief executive and managing director James Warburton steps down with immediate effect.

title.children: Seven West Media CEO James Warburton steps down

image.altText: Tim English and Rowan Marshall compete at a ruck contest during a Bulldogs, Saints, AFL match

props.synopsis: The Western Bulldogs and St Kilda are coming off losses in round 5 and meet at Docklands, each searching for their third win of the season. Follow live.

title.children: Saints and Dogs looking to turn fortunes around with a win on Thursday night

image.altText: Flowers in colour and the background in black and white.

props.synopsis: Australia's spy boss was asked why Monday night's church stabbing was ruled a terrorist attack, while Saturday's stabbing rampage — where one man and five women were killed in Bondi Junction — was not. He said it wasn't. But should it have been?

title.children: Could attacks on predominantly women ever be considered terrorism?

image.altText: Man looking off camera

props.synopsis: A shopping centre security guard who helped confront Bondi mass-murderer Joel Cauchi is likely to secure a permanent Australian visa, following the intervention of the prime minister.

title.children: Security guard stabbed in Bondi attack likely to get permanent visa, PM says

image.altText: AFP has charged a Brisbane man over an alleged drug plot

props.synopsis: The Federal Police allege Daniel Wayne Roberts is the Australian head of a transnational crime organisation behind cocaine plots in Queensland, Western Australia and NSW.

title.children: Brisbane man behind plot to import cocaine that later washed up on NSW beaches, AFP alleges

image.altText: Snowtown accomplice Mark Ray Haydon in a car being escorted from court.

props.synopsis: Snowtown accomplice Mark Ray Haydon is being slowly reintroduced to the community, with the head of SA's Parole Board saying the "world has changed a lot" since he was taken into custody and he needs to learn how to use a mobile phone, access Centrelink and catch public transport.

title.children: 'The world has changed a lot': Snowtown accomplice's transition to life after 25 years in jail

image.altText: Dr Corbin Barry

props.synopsis: The unemployment rate increased slightly to 3.8 per cent in March, after employment fell by 7,000 people and unemployment rose by 21,000 people.

title.children: Unemployment has gone up, but Corbin is finding it hard to keep staff long-term

image.altText: A composite image of three historical buildings, hills and clouds

props.synopsis: On Tasmania's wild west coast, towns have risen and fallen at the whim of industry. Some of their oldest living inhabitants remember their former homes, and how their communities came undone.

title.children: Tasmania is riddled with hundreds of fading and vanishing towns. Where did they go wrong?

image.altText: A man is led to a police car by two police officers. All have blurred faces.

props.synopsis: Five Australians are among 37 individuals who have been arrested in relation to an alleged global phishing scam that targeted tens of thousands of people, the Australian Federal Police said today.

title.children: Five arrested over global phishing scam that allegedly claimed about 94,000 Australian victims

image.altText: A plant with a long stem and purple flowers on the end

props.synopsis: Some plants seem full of promise and intrigue at the nursery, but are full of surprises later on — when they're threatening to overthrow the boundary fence. What are the common horticultural culprits?

title.children: Plants you shouldn't plant, according to the experts

image.altText: An artists impression of an ichthyosaur washed up on the beach.

props.synopsis: A fossil jawbone found by a young girl and her father on a beach in England belongs to a gigantic marine reptile dating back to 202 million years ago that appears to have been among the largest animals ever on Earth.

title.children: Gigantic marine reptile identified from fossil found by 11-year-old girl and father

image.altText: Yuja Wang plays a grand piano in front of an orchestra in a sparky red dress. Her right arm is thrown up dramatically.

props.synopsis: New York's famous Carnegie Hall tracked musician and audience heart rates during a live performance. The results show how in sync music can make us.

title.children: What happened when a concert pianist wore a heart rate monitor during a marathon performance

image.altText: Ella looks slightly to the left as she turns back while standing in a vault in her blue vault uniform.

props.synopsis: Critics and fans seem to agree that the television adaptation of Fallout doesn't miss. Here's why it's S.P.E.C.I.A.L! (that's a Fallout reference in case you didn't know).

title.children: There were fears about the Prime Video adaptation of beloved game Fallout. Here's why they nailed it

image.altText: A man holds hands with a kangaroo

props.synopsis: A Royal Flying Doctor Service pilot has shared a heartwarming interaction he had with a Kangaroo at the Port Augusta base when it approached him, paw outstretched.

title.children: Pilot and kangaroo hold hands in 'paw-some' airport encounter

image.altText: A child's legs seen running on the beach with water behind.

props.synopsis: Suicide prevention advocates speak of the devastation wrought on the family of a 10-year-old boy who died by suicide in state care, describing the emotional reaction of his parents after seeing their son's body.

title.children: 'It should be unimaginable': Suicide of 10-year-old boy in state care sparks outpouring of grief

image.altText: Wads of cash sitting on a shelf mounted on a corrugated iron wall.

props.synopsis: The trial of a Hunter Valley man charged with proceeds of crime offences is postponed, after a judge is told the legality of an app used by police to gather evidence against him is likely to be challenged in Australia's highest court.

title.children: Legality of AFP's encrypted Trojan horse app AN0M likely to be challenged in High Court, prosecutor says

image.altText: Two woman walk along a path in front of the beach, one of them is pushing a pram.

props.synopsis: Artificial intelligence support workers could be in Australia's future if the fertility rate continues to stay the same.

title.children: There's a baby drought in Australia. Here's why you should care

image.altText: Amy, a woman with blonde hair, looks serious in a portrait.

props.synopsis: HECS-HELP debts are forecast to rise between 4.2 and 4.8 per cent this year, the second-highest rise in a decade.

title.children: 'I wish I'd dropped out of school when I was 15': Looming HECS indexation worrying debtors as cost of living bites

image.altText: Indonesia volcano

props.synopsis: Indonesian authorities issue a tsunami alert after eruptions at Ruang mountain send ash thousands of feet high, with hundreds evacuated from the area.

title.children: Indonesia issues tsunami alert as volcano erupts

image.altText: A submarine with a red, white and blue flag on the front sits on an empty patch of concrete

props.synopsis: The US Navy's head of weapons acquisitions says they have "a long ways to go" to increase shipbuilding to the necessary level to deliver on the AUKUS agreement to provide nuclear-powered submarines to Australia.

title.children: 'Does not inspire confidence': Congress committee questions US Navy heads amid AUKUS fears

image.altText: A wide road covered in water with cars and trucks stuck in the middle.

props.synopsis: Speculation swirled on social media that the weather technology was to blame for the largest ever rainfall Dubai has seen. But experts say the record rains were on a totally different scale to what seeding would produce.

title.children: Speculation 'cloud seeding' caused Dubai record rainfall and floods shot down by experts

image.altText: A young woman faces another person, holding her hands and mouth in movement, as if in conversation.

props.synopsis: Author Charles Duhigg and broadcaster Beverley Wang have made a profession out of having good conversations. They share how deeper listening, laughing more, and slowing down can help.

title.children: The simple skills that can help you have deeper conversations
